OwnerUser.AboutMe: I'm a professor of linguistics at MIT. I work on meaning. I am also Associate Dean of MIT's School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences. I have a wife, two kids, two cats, and a dog. I live in an intentional community (Mosaic Commons Cohousing) in Berlin, Massachusetts. I am a runner. I like soccer, a lot. I was born on a cold winter’s night in a small village on the Lüneburg Heath in Northern Germany.

Body:
I'm not an expert on this topic but these are some of the most relevant works:

  • Den Dikken, Marcel. 2006. Either-float and the syntax of co-or-dination. Natural Language and Linguistic Theory 24(3). 689–749. http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11049-005-2503-0.
  • Johannessen, Janne Bondi. 2005. The syntax of correlative adverbs. Lingua 115(4). 419–443. http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.lingua.2003.09.009.
  • Larson, Richard K. 1985. On the syntax of disjunction scope. Natural Language and Linguistic Theory 3(2). 217–264. http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/BF00133841.
  • Schwarz, Bernhard. 1999. On the syntax of either ... or. Natural Language and Linguistic Theory 17(2). 339–370. http://dx.doi.org/10.1023/A:1006046306942.

As usual, you can find more relevant literature on the topic by perusing the bibliographies of these works and/or exploring via Google Scholar who has been citing them. Larson and Schwarz are the pivotal contributions. Johannessen gives a fairly non-technical cross-linguistic perspective.
